member.name: T:White.NUnit.Verify
member.summary: Allows you to perform verifications in your tests. This does the same thing as the corresponding Assert methods in NUnit do, only difference being it doesn't stop the test at that point. Since functional tests are long running tests, hence one would want to know about all the failures in the in one go. One should still use NUnit Assert directly in situations where there is no point in proceeding with the test.

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.AreEqual``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0})
member.summary: Verifies that two lists have the same elements

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.AreNotEqual(System.Object,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies that two objects are not equal and prints message if they are equal

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.IsTrue(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies that a condition is true and prints the message if it is false

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.IsFalse(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies that a condition is false and prints the message if it is true

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.CleanUp
member.summary: This should be called at the end of every test so that the failures of one test should not appear as failure on other tests.

member.name: M:White.NUnit.Verify.Perform(White.NUnit.Verify.AssertDelegate,System.Object[])
member.summary: Executes user provided method but does not stop the test if the Assertion fails

member.name: P:White.NUnit.Verify.TestFailed
member.summary: Check whether the test failed or succeeded. This would get reset to false when CleanUp is called.

member.name: P:White.NUnit.Verify.Failures
member.summary: Get the stacktrace of all the failures. The StackTrace can be printed out using System.Console.WriteLine.
